bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, November 9, 1921

div1.p: Hanson hopes that there will be no more yellow fever cases after the year 1921. He describes his field work in detail: the use of fish to combat mosquito breeding was very successful but the limited use of containers was difficult to enforce. He praises several inspectors for their good work.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, November 9, 1921
div1.opener:
Hanson
Nov. 9/21
DIRECCION DE LA CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN LOS
DEPARTAMENTOS DEL NORTE
---
OFICINA CENTRAL
-----
Aboard the SS Peru,
Enroute to Huacho and Lima.
November 9, 1921.
My Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I received your letter of October 10th on
the last mail that came in before I left Chiclayo last Sunday. I
was very glad indeed to get your letter; it is quite a help in
this lonesome situation to hear from some one who fully understands
and appreciates the situation. This job has been tremendously big
and has been associated with innumerable worries and difficulties.
At present we are most anxiously hoping that we shall be able to
say that there was no fever in Peru after the year 1921, but as yet
we can not be too sure about this. The other day we got a report
that a case had been declared in Callao by a Dr. Barton, whom Drs.
Mendoza, Benavides and Canseco say is a very relieble man. The usual
arguments seem to have arisen in Callao and Lima over this case. I
telegraphed the Salubridad for information, but up to the time that
I left Chiclayo I had not received any reply. This is characteris-
tic of them you know. I thought Wrightson might have done a little
better than that, he could at least have replied stating that the
thing was indefinite. In as much as I expected to come south for an
inspection, i.e., my regular monthly trip I decided to continue on to
Lima to get personal information, and have brought Dr. Mendoza and
Sr. Burga Cisneros and Insp. Olivari with me so as to be able to
start anything which may seem necessary when I get there.

Dr. Tapia came aboard in Salaverry and brought us the news th
that the case had died on the 5th day and the autopsy, (by a Dr. Alme-
nara) had shown it to be a case of severe malaria. I hope it is so.
Dr. Almenara is a very clever young physician who has done a great
deal of laboratory work, but whether he has enought experience with
yellow fever to dicide a thing of this kind I am not so certain.

This sort of introduces a possibility for the change of my plans
for the campaign. I had hoped that we could feel safe by extending
the campaign as far south as Huacho, and possibly taking in the vall
valley of the Chillon, just north of Lima. There are a great many haci-
endas there where there might be a lurking focus of infection, and
I had practically made all arrangements to clean those places up by
a vigorous fish campaign wherever this proved to be the most feasible
method. In fact I am quite convinced that it is about the only method
of choice for antistegomya work. Up to date we have used over 350 000
fish, with most excellent results. The container which has fish has no
larvae. The people are beginnig to recognize the fact also because
many who I meet in these ports tell me that at this time of the year
last year they were terribly annoyed with mosquitoes, and now they
never see or feel any. Such is the condition of the coast from
Huacho north, but we do not yet know what we have about Lima or
Callao. Wrightson and Richardson were doing some work there while
the campaign was going on, but as soon as we recommended suppressing
the quarantine restrictions against Libertad and Lambayeque they
stopped their antistegomya measures.

You undoubtedly remember the circumstance of the two Japs
who went from Ferreñafe to Lima and died there. Undoubtedly there
were other cases of the same nature, I kept getting reports of ru-
mored cases and kept after the Salubridad about the matter but they
seemed to think they knew more about the thing than I did, and never
made any efforts to investigate, and even discouraged Quiroz when I
wrote him to see the Salubridad about making a special investigation
to prove or disprove these rumors. I have several copies of letters
and telegrams in my files referring to this matter but unfortunately
these copies are of no value in rectifying the damage done. The prob-
lem of Callao or Lima or both, is not such an insuperable one, were it

not for the possibilities which it points out in regard to the south.
There are several places to the south of Lima where the temperature
is sufficiently high to have stegomya breeding, and if we find any
proofs of the genuineness of this case togather with the history of
other cases it seems that we will be obliged to make an investigation
of the territory to the south, however let us hope that this is all a
premature discussion.

I imagine that we probably could have gotten this fish in the
Chira river, probably not in the Piura because the latter goes dry.
The fish which is far the best of those we have tried is the “life”
I have tried to get a scientific classifacation of this fish but to
date have not succeeded. If I cant get this done in Lima I will send
some samples to Washington. I have a number of odds and ends of this
kind to attend to in Lima this time and will try to find out where
we can get this work done. The work of Corrigan and Sainz in the De-
partment of Ancash was a very brilliant demonstration of the effi-
casy of the fish. Unfortunately this fish is edible, and my men tell
me that we lose a great many fish in this way. We have calculated our
losses at about 2x 26%, most of it due to contrariness on the part of
the people. We are going to make a third trial with the small fish
of the type from Barbadoes, “milliones” as they call them here and in
Guayaquil. If we get them now at the beginning of the warm season we
may be able to get them aclamitized before the cold weather comes on
again. It seemed like the last batches we had died on account of the
cold weather coming on.

Limiting containers is a more difficult thing to enforce, when
one has as extensive a territory as that which we have this year. We
have worked to date in 75 towns and haciendas on the coast, and it
would take xxxxa numerous personnel to enforce the other methods (i.e. other than fish)
Casa Grande was practically the only hacienda in Libertad which had

the epidemic. In the Department of Lambayeque they all had it, and
much more of it than they cared to admit. than they cared to admit.

The Medico at Guadelupe turned out O.K. and he has been placed
in charge of the work in the Province of Pacasmayo. He is very much
interested and enthusiastic about the work. Arce at Salaverry is one
of the best men on the coast north of Lima. Dr. Tapia also has turned
out to be exceptionally valuable to the campaign. In fact I have more
confidence in him as a submanager than in almost any of the others.

I note what you say about emptying containers and the index,
in which I quite agree with you. The difficulty in emptying contain-
ers is that there is generally a scarcity of water, and it gives rice
to difficulties, on the part of the people. No question about it being
an effective method where it can be done.

In regard to the cement lined barrels we have since found
them breeding, but in each case it has been where the barrel had be-
come very dirty. Dunn scouts the idea that they do not breed as free-
ly in these as in other containers. We will wait and see.

The stegomya does lay her eggs on the water under artificial
conditions such as Dunn had in his laboratory experiments, but I do
not think they do unless forced to do so for lack of a wall to place
her eggs higher up.

Since writing the above Mr. Dunn has been aboard, as we are
now in the port of Huacho, and about to sail for Callao. Dunn seems
very much interested in the work and thoroughly impressed with the
extensiveness of the campaign. There is still so much field work to
be done that we find it a bit difficult to decide when to begin the
actual research work. I am very much pleased that I conceived the
idea of bringing Mr. Dunn down, he is a very good man for this kind
of work, and has ability and judgement and intelligence, which is
a great thing.

Well I must close for this time and write you again from Li
Lima after I get a room and get things sized up a bit.

With all good wishes, and many thanks for your most inter-
esting letter,
